description: Media magnate Rupert Murdoch, who is 93, married Elena Zhukova on Saturday.
title: Rupert Murdoch marries for 5th time in ceremony at California vineyard

description: The Dallas Stars face the Edmonton Oilers for Game 6 of the NHL Stanley Cup Playoffs Western Conference finals tonight.
title: How to watch Dallas Stars vs. Edmonton Oilers, Game 6

description: On this "Face the Nation" broadcast, former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York Preet Bharara and North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum join Margaret Brennan.
title: Full transcript of "Face the Nation," June 2, 2024

description: Taylor Momsen, whose band The Pretty Reckless are opening for AC/DC, was performing in Spain when she was bit by a bat.
title: Taylor Momsen bit by a bat while performing in Spain

description: The following is a transcript of an interview with former commander of U.S. forces in the Middle East, retired General Frank McKenzie, on "Face the Nation" that aired on June 2, 2024.
title: Transcript: Ret. Gen. Frank McKenzie on "Face the Nation," June 2, 2024

description: A pilot suffered non life-threatening injuries after being pulled from a burning helicopter that crashed in New Hampshire.
title: Pilot rescued from burning helicopter that crashed in New Hampshire

description: This week on "Face the Nation," Margaret Brennan speaks to Robert Costa and Jan Crawford in the aftermath of the historic guilty verdict in New York for former President Donald Trump. Former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Preet Bharara will discuss the verdict, and vice presidential contender North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum also joins.
title: 6/2: Face the Nation

description: You're not alone in being confused about whether biweekly means twice a week or every other week. Here's what the dictionary and experts say about definition confusion.
title: Does biweekly mean twice a week or twice a month?

description: While in office, Trump took issue with the social media app being controlled by a China-based parent company, trying unsuccessfully to ban the app in the U.S. with an executive order.
title: Donald Trump joins TikTok after reversal on app he tried to ban as president

description: Missed the second half of the show? The latest on... the 2024 election, relief for Palestinian refugees and a look at the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan.
title: Face The Nation: Burgum, McKenzie, Pottinger

description: North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum, a contender for Donald Trump's running mate, said Sunday that November's election will not be decided by the former president's guilty conviction in the New York "hush money" trial.
title: Burgum on Trump verdict: "The election is not gonna turn on this trial"

description: The following is a transcript of an interview with North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum on "Face the Nation" that aired on June 2, 2024.
title: Transcript: North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum on "Face the Nation," June 2, 2024

description: Scott Anderson, the director of UNRWA, the largest relief agency for Palestinian refugees, tells "Face the Nation" that what Palestinians are lacking are "just basic necessities that we all kind of expect." The "number-one concern," he added, is "access to clean drinking water."
title: Head of UN refugee efforts in Gaza says "number one concern" is clean drinking water

description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Matt Pottinger, who served as deputy National Security Adviser in the Trump administration, on "Face the Nation" that aired on June 2, 2024.
title: Transcript: Matt Pottinger, former deputy National Security Adviser, on "Face the Nation," June 2, 2024

description: Matt Pottinger served as deputy National Security Adviser under former President Donald Trump and resigned after Jan. 6, 2021, and later testified that national security was in harm that day and it gave ammunition to feed a narrative that our system of government doesn't work. Pottinger tells "Face the Nation" that "Election Day will be a referendum" if there is still faith in U.S. systems.
title: National security official says "Election Day will be a referendum" on faith in U.S. systems

description: Retired Gen. Frank McKenzie, the former commander of the U.S. forces in the Middle East, writes in a new book that the withdrawal from Afghanistan, which was negotiated under former President Donald Trump and implemented under President Biden, was "one of the worst negotiating mistakes by the U.S." Both presidents, McKenzie tells "Face the Nation," shared a policy objective of leaving Afghanistan, regardless of the consequences."
title: Ret. Gen. Frank McKenzie says Afghanistan withdrawal was "one of worst negotiating mistakes"

description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Scott Anderson, director of UNRWA Affairs in Gaza, on "Face the Nation" that aired on June 2, 2024.
title: Transcript: Scott Anderson, director of UNRWA Affairs in Gaza, on "Face the Nation," June 2, 2024

description: North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum, considered to be one of the contenders to be former President Donald Trump's running mate, tells "Face the Nation" that the 2024 election "is not going to turn on" Trump's conviction in New York.
title: North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum says 2024 election "is not going to turn on this trial"

description: Preet Bharara, the former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, tells "Face the Nation" that characterizations made by GOP Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida and fellow Republicans are "completely silly." "The trial, all aspects of the trial were done openly and in public," Bharara added.
title: Preet Bharara says characterizations by GOP of Trump's trial are "completely silly"

description: Former President Donald Trump was convicted last week of 34 felony counts of falsifying business records to cover up "hush money" payments to adult film star Stormy Daniels. Robert Costa and Jan Crawford discuss what could happen next.
title: What's next after Trump convicted of 34 felony counts

description: The following is a transcript of an interview with Preet Bharara, former U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York, on "Face the Nation" that aired on June 2, 2024.
title: Transcript: Preet Bharara, former U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York, on "Face the Nation," June 2, 2024

description: Chennedy Carter gave a shoulder shot to Clark that knocked her to the floor before an inbound pass during the third quarter of Saturday's 71-70 win by the Fever.
title: Carter's foul on Clark upgraded by WNBA; Reese fined for no postgame interview

description: Actor Michael Douglas sits down with Mo Rocca to discuss his series "Franklin," now streaming on Apple TV+. Then, Faith Salie visits Stumpy the cherry tree in Washington, D.C. before it was removed due to a repair project that will raise sea walls. "Here Comes the Sun" is a closer look at some of the people, places and things we bring you every week on "CBS Sunday Morning."
title: Here Comes the Sun: Michael Douglas and more

description: Neighborhoods southwest of Tracy were ordered to evacuate Saturday because of a wind-whipped wildfire that has grown to 12,500 acres Sunday morning and closed part of Interstate Highway 580.
title: Wind-driven Corral Fire burns 12,500 acres; fire crews grow containment to 15%

description: This week on "Face the Nation," Margaret Brennan speaks to Robert Costa and Jan Crawford in the aftermath of the historic guilty verdict in New York for former President Donald Trump. Former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Preet Bharara will discuss the verdict, and vice presidential contender North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum also joins.
title: Open: This is "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan," June 2, 2024

description: Nearly 100 million people are registered to vote in the race to replace outgoing President Andrés Manuel López Obrador.
title: Mexico votes in election likely to choose country's first female president

description: In this web extra, Katie Ledecky, author of "Just Add Water: My Swimming Life," talks with correspondent Elaine Quijano about recent reports that 23 Chinese swimmers had tested positive for a banned substance just months before competing at the Tokyo Games in 2021, and how the news affected her and her teammates.
title: Olympian Katie Ledecky on the Chinese doping investigation

description: We leave you this Sunday with orangutans, hanging out on the island of Borneo in southeast Asia. Videographer: Justin Grubb.
title: Nature: Orangutans in Borneo

description: The historian notes the felony conviction of a former American president by a jury of peers, proving all are equal under the law, would never have taken place in countries ruled by authoritarians.
title: Douglas Brinkley and the lesson of Trump's guilty verdict

description: An early morning shooting in Akron, Ohio killed one person and injured two dozen people, some critically, police said.
title: Shooting in Ohio kills 1, wounds 2 dozen others, police say

description: The historian notes the felony conviction of a former American president by a jury of peers, proving all are equal under the law, would never have taken place in countries ruled by authoritarians.
title: Douglas Brinkley and the lesson of Trump's guilty verdict

description: Responding to reports that Chinese swimmers tested positive for a banned substance just months before the 2021 Tokyo Games, Ledecky says, "Our faith in some of the systems is at an all-time low."
title: Swimmer Katie Ledecky on Chinese doping scandal and the Paris Olympics

description: Cyndi Lauper was a pop music dynamo and MTV-favorite singer who later won a Tony Award for her songs for the stage musical "Kinky Boots." But she wanted more than to just have fun. The subject of a new documentary on Paramount+ called "Let the Canary Sing," Lauper talks with correspondent Anthony Mason about how music made her tumultuous home life better; how she had to be convinced about her breakout record, "Girls Just Want to Have Fun"; and about criticism from producer Quincy Jones that she was a "troublemaker."
title: Cyndi Lauper: Showing her true colors

description: Former President Donald Trump's critics have been vocal about what a potential Trump election victory in November might mean for the country. In a visit to a campaign rally in Schnecksville, Pennsylvania, "Sunday Morning" senior contributor Ted Koppel talks with Trump supporters to find out what they believe would be the consequences of another Trump election loss. He also visits the battlefield at Gettysburg, where a "war on memory" continues to be waged.
title: Reality, as Trump supporters see it

description: In 2018 a federal appeals court decided that Boise, Idaho's camping ban – used to deter the homeless from sleeping on the streets – was "cruel and unusual punishment." Grants Pass, Oregon, has now challenged that argument before the Supreme Court.
title: The Supreme Court case that could impact the homeless coast-to-coast

description: In 2018 many Western officials were outraged by a 9th Circuit Court of Appeals decision that said Boise, Idaho's ban on camping outdoors – aimed at deterring homeless people from sleeping on the streets – was "cruel and unusual punishment" prohibited by the 8th Amendment of the Constitution. Now, the city of Grants Pass, Oregon, has challenged that argument before the Supreme Court, and what the Court decides will impact how all cities and counties across the country can handle the unhoused. Correspondent John Blackstone reports.
title: The Supreme Court to rule on laws impacting the homeless

description: Katie Ledecky won her first Olympic gold at age 15, and today has more individual Olympic gold medals than any woman swimmer in history. As she gears up for the Paris Olympics this summer, Ledecky talks with correspondent Elaine Quijano about reexamining the results of the 2021 Tokyo Games after news that Chinese swimmers had tested positive for a banned substance just months before the competition. She also talks about her preparations for the Paris Games, the 2028 Olympics in Los Angeles, and beyond.
title: Katie Ledecky on sports doping and the Paris Olympics

description: "Sunday Morning" remembers some of the notable figures who left us this week, including NBA Hall of Famer and sportscaster Bill Walton.
title: Passage: In memoriam

description: When the "Jurassic Park" writer died in 2008, he left behind an unfinished novel about a volcanic eruption that imperils all life on Earth. Enter bestselling author James Patterson, tasked with completing Crichton's thriller.
title: How James Patterson completed Michael Crichton's "Eruption"

description: Writer Michael Crichton, whose blockbuster novels, films and TV series included "Jurassic Park" and "ER," died in 2008, leaving behind an unfinished thriller about a volcanic eruption that imperils all life on Earth. Bestselling author James Patterson was tasked with completing Crichton's book, and now, 16 years later, "Eruption" is finally being unleashed in bookstores. Correspondent Tracy Smith talks with Patterson, and with Michael's widow, Sherri Alexander Crichton, about bringing back the voice of a master storyteller.
title: James Patterson on completing Michael Crichton's "Eruption"

description: "Sunday Morning" looks back at historical events on this date.
title: Almanac: June 2

description: The new Broadway show "Illinoise" is a choreographed indie-rock musical with no dialogue, based on Sufjan Stevens' 2005 concept album. It's received four Tony Award nominations, including best musical. "Sunday Morning" contributor Kelefa Sanneh talks with choreographer Justin Peck, playwright Jackie Sibblies Drury, and musician Shara Nova about the show, an ode to the origins of storytelling and theatre-making.
title: "Illinoise" and the origin of an unlikely Broadway musical

description: Being found guilty of 34 felony counts would normally mark the end of someone's political prospects. But this week's conviction is not stopping Trump (who has built his career, and brand, on grievances) from running for another term in the White House.
title: Trump's guilty verdict: A stress test for democracy

description: Being found guilty of 34 felony counts would normally mark the end of someone's political prospects. But as longtime Trump chronicler Michael Wolff notes, the former president has built his career, and brand, on grievances – and this week's conviction in a New York courtroom is not stopping Trump from running for another term in the White House. CBS News chief election & campaign correspondent Robert Costa reports.
title: Trump's guilty verdict: A stress test for democracy

description: Half the country says Trump is not fit to be president; Republicans call the trial unfair, according to CBS News poll.
title: Views of Trump trial unchanged following verdict — CBS News poll

description: Three C-47 transport planes, a workhorse of World War II, dropped three long strings of jumpers, their round chutes mushrooming open in the blue skies with puffy white clouds.
title: Parachute jump kicks off commemorations for the 80th anniversary of D-Day

description: The "Sunday Morning" book reviewer offers his picks from this month's new fiction and non-fiction titles, including "Eruption," a thriller started by Michael Crichton and finished, more than 15 years after Crichton's death, by James Patterson.
title: 6/2: The Book Report by Washington Post critic Ron Charles

description: South Korea says it'll take strong retaliatory steps against North Korea over its launch of trash-carrying balloons across the border and other provocations.
title: South Korea pledges retaliation against North over trash-filled balloons

description: This month's fiction and non-fiction titles include an unfinished thriller by "Jurassic Park" author Michael Crichton, completed more than 15 years after Crichton's death by bestselling writer James Patterson.
title: The Book Report: Washington Post critic Ron Charles (June 2)

description: A delightful mix of historical fact and science fiction, this debut novel mixes historical fact and science fiction in the story of a secret British agency that plucks doomed people from the past.
title: Book excerpt: "The Ministry of Time" by Kaliane Bradley

description: The British journalist and author of "Midnight in Chernobyl" returns with his exhaustively-researched new book about the 1986 space shuttle disaster.
title: Book excerpt: "Challenger" by Adam Higginbotham

description: We head to SoCal to experience some of Tinseltown's most delicious eats, from a pizzeria introducing Los Angeles to Pittsburgh-style pies to a Santa Monica spot serving up a combination of flavors from California and France. Watch these stories and more on The Dish.
title: The Dish: Los Angeles restaurants

description: The bestselling author of "The Emperor's Children" returns with a multi-generational story of family secrets spanning World War II to the 21st century.
title: Book excerpt: "This Strange Eventful History" by Claire Messud

description: When Becky Bliefnick was murdered, an answer her husband gave on "Family Feud" years earlier raised eyebrows. "48 Hours" correspondent Erin Moriarty reports.
title: The Game Show and the Murder

description: A photographer who was on "The Dating Game" became one of the nation's deadliest serial killers. Eight years after "48 Hours"' first report, new victims emerge. Correspondent Peter Van Sant reports.
title: Rodney Alcala: The Killing Game

description: Boeing Starliner launch scrubbed yet again; Beloved surfboard-stealing otter spotted again off Northern California coast
title: 6/1: CBS Weekend News

description: The problems began Friday morning, causing water problems at two hospitals, a city jail, a county jail and local shelters.
title: Atlanta water main break causes major disruptions, closures

description: Prosecutors say evidence, including damning cellphone searches and texts, led them to Tim Bliefnick for the February murder of Becky Bliefnick.
title: Illinois man convicted of killing his wife speaks out: "I'm innocent."

description: Police say a photographer and one-time contestant on "The Dating Game" was also a chameleon and a serial killer —perhaps the deadliest in U.S. history.
title: Serial killer Rodney Alcala's trail of murder

description: Last summer, otter 841 terrorized surfers in Santa Cruz, California, biting surfboards and even hijacking them. Now she has returned.
title: Beloved surfboard-stealing otter spotted again off Northern California shore

description: Two days after he was convicted of triple-murder, an Idaho jury on Saturday sentenced Chad Daybell to death in the 2019 killing of his first wife, Tammy Daybell, and the killings of the two youngest children of his now wife, Lori Vallow Daybell. In 2023, Vallow Daybell was also convicted in the murders of those two children and sentenced to life in prison.
title: Chad Daybell sentenced to death in murders of first wife, ex-girlfriend's 2 children

description: Following former President Donald Trump's conviction in his New York "hush money" trial, voters in the battleground state of Pennsylvania spoke to Nikole Killion about whether Trump's legal troubles will impact their vote.
title: Pennsylvania voters respond to Trump conviction

description: Former President Donald Trump on Friday lashed out at his conviction in his New York "hush money" trial, making several false claims, while upside down flags, a symbol of protest adopted by the MAGA movement, were on display at Trump Tower. President Biden called Trump's remarks "reckless" and "dangerous." Natalie Brand reports from Washington.
title: Presidential election enters uncharted territory after Trump verdict

description: The African National Congress party, once led by the late Nelson Mandela, has lost its parliamentary majority for the first time since 1994, when it helped bring about the end of apartheid.
title: South Africa's ruling party loses its majority for first time in 3 decades

description: What was to be the maiden launch of the Boeing Starliner with astronauts on board was halted yet again Saturday, this time less than four minutes before liftoff, when a computer system triggered an automatic hold. A launch last month was also canceled due to various issues. Manuel Bojorquez has the latest.
title: Boeing Starliner launch scrubbed yet again

description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu Saturday indicated that Israel would not agree to a cease-fire until certain conditions are met, including the return of all hostages and the elimination of Hamas' military and governing capabilities. This seemed to contradict President Biden's announcement Friday that Israel had extended a new cease-fire proposal. Imtiaz Tyab reports from Tel Aviv.
title: Netanyahu indicates no cease-fire until Israel's objectives are achieved

description: Here's a look at the top stories making headlines on the "CBS Weekend News" with Nancy Cordes.
title: "CBS Weekend News" headlines for Saturday, June 1, 2024

description: Last summer, otter 841 terrorized surfers in Santa Cruz, California, biting surfboards and even hijacking them. Now she has returned. Carter Evans has more.
title: Beloved surfboard-stealing otter spotted again off Northern California coast

description: A new study has found that Colorado's fourteener mountains, which are those over 14,000 feet in elevation, are a bit shorter than originally thought. The new findings have wide implications. Shaun Boyd explains.
title: Colorado's famous fourteener mountains get new elevations

description: More than 16 million Americans served in World War II, but now only about 100,000 are still alive. The National World War II Museum in New Orleans is working to teach their stories to a new generation. Barry Petersen has more.
title: New Orleans museum works to preserve the stories of World War II veterans

description: The spacecraft, part of the Chang'e moon exploration program, will collect soil and rock samples.
title: Chinese spacecraft lands on far side of moon

description: Almost 160,000 Allied troops landed at Normandy on June 6, 1944, in a massive operation designed to break through heavily fortified German defenses and begin the liberation of Western Europe.
title: World War II veterans travel to France to commemorate 80th anniversary of D-Day

description: Key West, Florida is known for its stunning views and sandy beaches, but chickens really rule the area. Local officials are trying to crack down on them, but it's impossible to fully get rid of the birds, who have been in the area since the 1800s.
title: Meet the surprising figures who rule the roost in Key West

description: Trump vows to appeal conviction in New York City hush money trial; Rett Madison talks inspiration behind new album "One for Jackie"
title: 6/1: Saturday Morning
